title: Brexit delay could see a cut in interest rates, warns ratesetter
text:
Interest rates may need to be cut if Brexit is delayed again, one of the Bank's ratesetters has said.

He warned that would come at a time when the Bank of England's 'total monetary firepower' is 'considerably less' than before the previous recession.

'A scenario of entrenched Brexit uncertainty is likely to keep economic growth below potential, and require some monetary stimulus,' said Gertjan Vlieghe, a member of the Bank's Monetary Policy Committee.

Gertjan Vlieghe said 'Brexit uncertainty' could require monetary stimulus

But speaking at the MMF Monetary and Financial Policy Conference in London, he added: 'We are not at the point where monetary policy has run out of ammunition, but the risk of that happening in the future has clearly risen relative to the pre-crisis period.'

His comments follow similar suggestions voiced at the last MPC meeting, when the Bank said there could be room to lower rates if Brexit was delayed once more.

Last month, another policymaker, Michael Saunders, claimed the Bank could cut interest rates even if Britain ends up with a Brexit deal.

He said at the time: 'If the UK avoids a no-deal Brexit, monetary policy also could go either way and I think it is quite plausible that the next move in the bank rate would be down rather than up.'

Vlieghe, however, said today that if a deal can be reached even at this late stage, then the Bank may yet be able to hold off from rate cuts.

'A near-term Brexit deal that reduces uncertainty and gives businesses adequate time to prepare for any future changes in the UK-EU trading relationship might yet stimulate investment sufficiently to prevent the need for easier monetary policy, and put gradual and limited rate hikes back on the agenda, eventually,' he said.

The Bank's base rate currently stands at 0.75 per cent.

However, not all rate-setters are of the same opinion.

The Bank's deputy governor Sir Dave Ramsden said in an interview with The Daily Telegraph on Monday that the UK's slower 'speed limit' for growth could weaken the case for lower rates.

At one stage, the Bank had said it may need to raise rates even in a no-deal Brexit if a plunging pound sends inflation far above target, though MPC members have been rowing back on this in recent months to stress a cut would be more likely.

It comes as official figures last week showed the economy contracted by 0.1 per cent in August as Brexit uncertainty weighed heavy.

But but a better-than-previously thought performance in July is expected to help the UK avoid recession, with growth standing at 0.3 per cent in the three months to August.
